componentInstanceProperties.name: bannerTitle
componentInstanceProperties.value: Why Democratisation of the Capital Markets is More Important Than Ever Before

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: VentureCrowd's Co-founder and CEO Steve Maarbani on why democratisation of the capital markets is more important than ever before.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
"Democracy is disruptive... there is no right in a democratic civil society to be free of disruption."

~ Naomi Wolf

This year, we’ve witnessed massive disruption, actual wars, boardroom coups, and sudden plot twists that have shocked and bewildered us. 

And, amid the unfolding disruption is a dysfunctional capital market that continues to make the rich richer and the poor poorer, that leaves fledgling companies exposed and in the cold, and whole economies in danger. The strain is palpable. 

However, despite all the uncertainty and heartache the world has experienced over the past year, what is clear is that doing things the way we’ve always done them is not going to change anything. We need to act differently if we are to achieve different outcomes.

Our only shot of changing the game is levelling the playing field by seeking the alternatives.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
It’s been nearly a year since the birth of ChatGPT3, something that has been so disruptive that it’s now being used by virtually everyone from high school students to CEOs. And, as we near the end of 2023, it’s clear this is only the beginning. Most recently, there’s been talk of a breakthrough in the development of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) that is sending shivers down the spines of Terminator fans and policy-makers alike.

Since OpenAI launched ChatGPT3 (and now 4), a flurry of new startups launched GPT-wrappers to leverage OpenAI’s APIs and develop niche products and others bunkered down to develop competing products. But, on November 7, OpenAI made an announcement that would spell the death knell for thousands of minnow-sized startups, and a few bigger fish as well. They launched a GPT “agent” marketplace and new developments in a plethora of other features, including enhanced text-to-speech (TTS) and ChatGPT4-Turbo, has destroyed many companies’ prospects in the process and also posed a massive threat to industry incumbents like Google. 

Then this was followed by the most bizarre dethroning we’ve seen in Silicon Valley since Jobs was ousted from Apple, the firing of OpenAI’s CEO, Sam Altman on November 17. Oh the irony of a very human drama putting an AI company in jeopardy. And we were worried about the robots. 

In the week following there was a massive plot twist with Sam Altman being reinstated as CEO, after hundreds of employees threatened to leave and follow him over to Microsoft (who own a 49% stake in OpenAI and who had offered Altman a job in the wake of his removal as CEO). 

What has emerged in the wake of this is a discussion around safety and ethics. Nobody wants a singularity (except the Terminator fans who side with the robots). It seems that the reason Sam was ousted in the first place was because of concerns that guardrails weren’t being implemented adequately and the board panicked. Again, the irony.

We don’t yet know if this major leader in the AI race will come out on top or if it will collapse. We also don’t know what all this means for humanity, let alone investors. But it all creates massive uncertainty and if investing continues to be the realm of the few, the subsequent inertia that typically results when macroeconomic forces are at play, could have a devastating impact on innovation.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
On October 7, the world woke to the horrific news about a Hamas attack in Israel and then, subsequently, the world’s eyes turned to the unfolding crisis in Gaza. To say there’s been tension in the world as a result is putting it lightly, and while the world watches the unfolding humanitarian crisis in Gaza and holds out hope for hostages to be safety returned to their loved ones in Israel, the ripple effect of geopolitical conflict in such a pivotal region is playing out behind the scenes.

Let me explain.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: Source: visualcapitalist.com

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
In the last century, we have become conditioned to believe that only certain groups of people, more capable than ourselves, are equipped to make the important decisions that affect our world and our lives.

That infamous group of gurus known only as ‘they’ have it all under control. Right? 

Over several generations, the few have made profit-led decisions that have led to an over-reliance on commodities like oil, sugar, rice, wheat, and corn. And this over-reliance has resulted in environmental damage, regional conflicts and health problems like obesity, diabetes and heart disease in epic proportions. 

Worse still, when war breaks out in regions that supply the bulk of these commodities, supply is constrained, prices go up everywhere, people go hungry, health is put at risk and the daily goods and services we all rely on become significantly less reliable, especially if you live in a low-income country. 

We saw this with the Ukraine War, and experts predict that the world will experience a dual energy shock because of the current conflict in the Middle East. Some analysts believe the current crisis will further impact inflation and potentially tip the world into recession. 

Analysts from Barrow Hanley suggest that the current conflict will result in sustained price rises, which is not good news for central banks trying to stabilise inflation. Others believe that economies will head back towards an equilibrium. 

We don’t yet know but we do know that if the few continue to make all the decisions on what we produce and consume, nothing will change.

The simple reason is that the few making the decisions are unlikely to prioritise the greater good.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: Why empower the many to invest

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
The only way we’re going to shock the system and bring change to the capital markets is to empower the many to back what will make a difference to people and the planet, what is for the greater good. 

If we want better health and wellbeing, we need to support more startups that are reducing sugar intake, helping people overcome diabetes and preventing heart disease. If we want a sustainable planet, we need to explore alternative foods and farming methods, implement renewable energy initiatives on a grand scale to reduce our dependence on coal, gas and oil, reduce carbon emissions and rejuvenate and protect our wild places and indigenous peoples. We need to adopt regenerative thinking which recognises the cultural, environmental, social and health systems as important factors in innovation over profit-driven thinking, which prioritises the financial gains above and at the expense of everything else.

None of this will happen unless we democratise capital raising and open the markets up to a broader range of investors.

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value: The new capital market is coming

componentInstanceProperties.name: richTextValue
componentInstanceProperties.value:
What is exciting is that this is already happening thanks to digital investing technology and changes in government regulations around who can invest and in what.

And this will enable a new breed of consumers and investors to drive change. What we’re seeing is a trend towards acting with a level of consciousness that has been absent during previous periods of economic growth, periods that will be infamously remembered for the unbridled pursuit of profit at all costs and the cause of many of the global challenges we now face amid all the disruption.

As we enter an era that promises so much potential, great founders will step into the light as they always have.

Supporting them will require us to laser-focus attention on the levers that best advance innovation and entrepreneurship. Talent, technology infrastructure, culture, professional services, legislative frameworks, founding teams’ health and mental wellbeing and, last but not least, capital will need to be front and centre.

And while we wait for the ripple effect of disruption to play out, the good news is that we can take action to challenge the status quo right now. 

So, take a deep breath in. Exhale fully. Now, let’s do this! 

Steve Maarbani - Co-founder and CEO, VentureCrowd

P.S. To learn more about investing in companies making an impact in these disruptive times, book a call with one of our friendly team members today.
